text: Bottle from the north coast store in Fort Bragg. Aroma sends shivers up my spine, the chocolate and bourbon blends so well. Flavor also brings up lots of chocolate flavors with the bourbon up front and the alcohol clearing the palate quickly with a bit of sweet sticky finish.

2013 vintage draft at Bru Craft during a North Coast event. Nearly opaque dark brown pour with overflowing foam - difficult pour. Huge, rich, pungent toffee caramel flavors. Chocolate bourbon. Raspberry orange. Cherry raisin. Vanilla oak. Plum pudding. Candied ginger. Black liquorice. Celery stalks. Giant, dark, foreboding, complex, and wonderful! A galaxy of flavor in every sip!

Bottle share at BitterCreek, 2009 vintage. Mahogany pour,small thin head. Bourbon, boozy aroma, some vanilla and molasses. Taste comes on sweet, rich malts, caramel wooden barrel flavors. Big, bold, boozy classic old ale.

Dark brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, oak, vanilla, maple, toffee, some dark fruit, & rich bourbon; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel, molasses, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruit, and nice bourbon; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & quite complex; Oh so smooth - love the bourbon!
Nice smooth old ale with copper color. Oily, smooth palate. Big aromas and flavors of bourbon, caramel, oak and graininess.
Nice spicy banan aroma, very good one of the best in style that I could ever drank

(500ml 2013 bottle from Systembolaget web order shared) Pours mahogany with a small loose white ring of bubbles. Aroma heavily burnt sugar, char, moderate bourbon notes, some vanilla, wood. Flavour is very balanced, with a rich caramel, totally burnt sugar, and aged bourbon base profile, toasted wood and some char, subtle dried fruits, light grain. Finish is long rich malt and wood layers, a panoply of ways sugar can be cooked or burnt, and wood can be toasted. Medium-full body with average carbonation. Maybe its age but the barrel here was quite subtle and integrated compared to the wheat whiskey version, not so flashy but more to explore and consider. Very nice.

Bottle 2009 vintage shared by alexsdad06 pour hazy cola brown with no head. Nose caramel, toffee, raisins, molasses. Taste raisins, molasses, prune, and only a hint of bourbon late. Some burn from alcohol. A little thin on the mouth feel.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer & Beyond. Thanks DSG. 2013 bottle. Murky burnt sienna. Sweet, vanilla and honey and maple in the nose, sweet, deep honey and a little bitter taste, also a little alcoholic. Full body, slightly carbonated, long, sweet finish.

Bottled 375ml (Systembolaget vintage 2013)
Deep ruby color, small beige head. Lots of toffee, vanilla and light alcohol in the nose. Medium-bodied. Mellow bourbon vanilla, maltyness in the flavor. Warming alcohol. Sweet robust vanilla beer. Excellent sippable brew and aged nicely.

Aroma is fruity, rum raisin, some alcohol, mild wood, vanilla as well as some nice mellow whiskey notes. Flavour is rum raisins, mellow whiskey, some alcohol and rather sweet sugary notes. Yet so very balanced and beautiful. Delicious.

14,1 %-os főzet a 2013-as old ale, ez a két adat már megfelelő alap lehet a bizakodáshoz, ha egy kivételes italban reménykedünk. Jeges tea színű teste szinte hab nélkül fejlődik, láthatóan a pezsgős dugótól történő megszabadítását követően sem indult meg a sör. Illataitól valósággal hátrahőkölhetünk, elementáris bourbon aromák robbannak szét a levegőben. Ázott tölgyhordó, de nem akármilyen, olajos gabonapárlatok puhította fadongák karaktere áthatolhatatlan illatréteget alkot, melybe zabolázhatatlan alkoholos jegyek szövődnek a meggymagos, mandulás, marcipános likőrök emlékét is megidézve. A test élénk, brutálisan alkoholos, valószínűleg a szerkezet jellegéből adódóan üt át jobban a szeszes hangulat, de kárára semmiképpen nem válik az italnak, ugyanis a karakter erre van kitalálva, megfelelő a terep a csípős, melengető elemek letaglózó szerepléséhez. Vanília, karamell, borókabogyó, szárított-cukrozott paradicsom, kevés áfonya és alma erjesztett jegyei fonódnak egybe a masszív, whiskys lenyomat súlya alatt, követhetetlen sokszínűséggel, minden figyelmet magához ragadó vadsággal, lenyűgöző összetettséggel. Meghálálja, hogy kiszabadult a palackból, egyszerinek és megismételhetetlennek tűnik a felejthetetlen szereplés.

Bottle shared at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. 2013 bottle. Hazy amber. Great aroma of bourbon, vanilla, malt, caramel, cookies, nuts. Sweet flavor with malt, bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, cookies, and a bit of alcohol. Medium to full-bodied, rounded mouthfeel. A great sipper.

26-NOV-2016, bottle @home, from Systembolaget, brought by Erik.
Hazy dark borwn with a low off-white head.
Alcohol, Bourbon, caramel, dried fruit. Sweet, full body. Fantastic and complex.

At the Beer and Beyond shop, Pours red to brown with small beige head, aroma of coconut, vanilla, wood, toffee, chocolate, flavor of bourbon, vanilla, coconut, toffee, caramel, medium bodied, very nice

Bottle shared by Jessic H. thanks. Nice but small light brown head. Dark brown color. Big vanilla aroma with almond oil. Smooth and mild balanaced bitterness. Fine sweet chocolate taste and a big body.

500ml bottle from Systembolaget, vintage 2013. Hazy mahogany, particles floating around in the glass, fizzy tan head that eventually disappears completely without leaving any lacing. Rich and rounded bourbon aroma, oak, dark dried fruit and vanilla. Full-bodied, soft carbonated, silky and chewy mouthfeel. Soft rounded malty, warming bourbon taste, dried fruit, figs, vanilla, woody, oak and a hit of tobacco. Solid barrel aging with a warming finish that lingers.

Arome: molasses, vanilla, toffee, figs, alcohol, dried fruits
Taste: heavy sweet, figs, vanilla, marshmallow, oak, alcohol, prune
2013 bottle. Boozy with caramel and barrel and some sticky brandy port notes. Nice.

750ml bottle "09 Vintage (Binnys)-44° in Snifter-Pours a reddish brown with a small white ring for a head. Aroma of bourbon, dried fruit, malt, and caramel. Taste of the same with molasses, tobacco, and sweetness. This full bodied brew is a nice sipping on a cool night kinda brew. Great brew.

500ml bottle from Systembolaget (Sweden).

Vintage 2013.


Dark reddish brown colour with a small white head. Bourbon, vanilla, oak, sweetness, overdone fruits, warming alcohol. Good, good, goooood. 500ml all by myself.
Clear reddish brown pour. Aroma is bourbon forward. Taste is bourbon, vanilla and licorice. Great stuff if you love bourbon.

500 ml bottle to snifter (2013 vintage, shared with the Mrs.). Looks good; a chewy dark amberish brown with off-white head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells good too; a nice balance of caramel, vanilla, oak, and hops. Tastes like it smells with a medium full-bodied mouthfeel thats very smooth for the abv. Tasty.

A: Deep brown coloured with a one finger off white head that dissapates fast. N: Vanilla, figs, bourbon, hint of apricot and dates. T: Liqourice, vanilla, molasses O: Very deep flavours and nice barrel aging. Nice!

2013 bottle from Greg (gregwilsonstl) -- cheers! Theres a ton of barrel-aged flavor and aroma as soon as I opened the bottle. Sweet, caramel flavor thats dried out a bit from three years in the bottle, but with so much bourbon and dry oak flavor that it almost tastes like a sweet bourbon. Great stuff.
2013 bottle. Pours a reddish brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, bourbon, vanilla, and some dark fruit.

How: Bottle.
Where: Tasting 2016-05-28.
Appearance: Amber-red colour with a quickly fading off-white head.
Aroma: Bourbon, alcohol, dried fruit, vanilla, raisin, caramel.
Body: Full body, low carbonation.

A consistently great if pricey beer, the sweetness of the bourbon meshes well with the fruitiness and creates a complex monster. Its too boozy and sweet compared to the complex yet more delicate base imo.

Dark amber/brown color, hazy. Lovely nose, sweet caramel and fruits and lot of bourbon barrel aromas and vanilla. Sweet taste of bourbon, vanilla, caramel and a lingering alcohol taste that warms your whole being. Long, awesome finish.

Bottle. 2013 vintage. Light hazy deep mahogany color with medium, fast dissipating off-white head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, sweet booze, raw sugar and red berries. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of booze, bourbon, wood and raw sugar. Full bodied with low to medium carbonation. Pretty nice, but a bit overly booze.

375 ml bottle. 2013 vintage.
Pours dark mahogany color with a very small head. Aroma is extremely pleasant bourbon-y with vanilla, quite dry wooden notes, caramel and some malts. Flavor is dry malty, refined with subtle wooden tingliness and slight alcohol burn, vanilla and ripe fruits on the sweet side. An excellent slow sipper, the aroma alone is intoxicating. Bourbon is strong with this one, this is still somewhat balanced though. Most likely will work quite perfectly as a slow sipper when slightly chilled. The alcohol cuts the sweetness nicely.

Flavour of toasted malts, tangy wood notes, fudge, some chocolate, bourbon, raisins and warming alcohol. Full bodied. Warming, sweet, bourbon finish. Very elegant. The bourbon here is very well presented.

Finish is sweetish, heavy and woody with some oak, bourbon, vanilla, ripe fruits, plum and warming alcohol. Loads of bourbon here.

2013 edition.

500 ml bottle into snifter; 2013 vintage, bottled in early 2015. Pours fairly cloudy deep reddish brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of huge raisin, plum, fig, date, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, coconut, toasted oak, bourbon, light leather, and oak/toasted earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel notes; with great strength. Taste of big raisin, plum, fig, date, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, coconut, toasted oak, bourbon, light leather, and oak/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, fig, date, caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, coconut, toasted oak, bourbon, light leather, and oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Incredible complexity, robustness, and and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; with a great malt/oak spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy and lightly slick/sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with only a light-moderate warmth lingering after the finish. Minimal booziness overall in aromas and flavors. Overall this is an absolutely incredible barrel aged old ale style. All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the huge ABV. An insanely enjoyable and delicious offering.

Take an excellent Old Ale and age it in bourbon barrel and youre probably going to end up with something great. Thats the premise of North Coast Old Stock 2013 Cellar Reserve, and the result is a delectable, sweet beastly brew thats remarkably drinkable. My only complaint is that its merely excellent rather than world class.

I poured a 500ml corked and cage bottle into a flared snifter (thanks to Patrick at the brewery for the bottle!).

Appearance: A hazy shade of murky burgundy to brown proper. Completely opaque. Pours to a small, off-white, soapy head which fizzles away quickly and completely.

Smell: Lovely scent of dark fruit, chocolate and bourbon though not especially pungent.

Taste: Theres a lot going on in this beer and its all pretty tasty to say the least. The base brew has a sweet, authentic palette of dark and dried fruits: plum, raisin, fig, cherry, dates, etc. But thats after the light milk chocolate sensation which opens each swig. On the finish the bourbon barrel appears to impart an earthy woody character, some vanilla and a hint of smoke. Alcohol grows stronger on each sip and becomes ever so slightly distracting. Theres an aftertaste of fruit and dark malt, though its only temporary. Hops have nearly completely receded  only the faintest bitterness is detectable. Overall, its what I would consider a great-tasting brew.

Drinkability: At 14.1% ABV, North Coast Old Stock 2013 Cellar Reserve is a big beer by anyones definition. Yet, its not quite the behemoth I was expecting. Yes, theres considerable warmth from the alcohol, but never is it out of control. The mouthfeel is not quite carbonated syrup; in fact, its a little lighter than I was expecting. As sweet as the palette is, it doesnt leave a sticky, cloying sensation (perhaps it should?). I was able to drink the entire bottle myself on a hot summers night (for whatever thats worth).

Score: 9/10

Palate lingers nicely, and fades into happiness.

Deep brownish red with a medium sized, quicjly dissipating, off-white head. Aroma is bourbon, caramel, figs, raisins, vanilla, light oak notes. Taste is medium sweet toffee, vanilla, dried fruit, alcohol, medium bitter, very slight oxidized. Finish is quite bitter with warming alcohol together with sweet vanilla, toffee and bourbon. Medium bodied, soft to average carbonation, a bit thinner and more carbonation then expected.

2013 reserve bottle. Appearance is deep brown caramel. Aroma is bourbon. Taste is brown sugar, oak, vanilla, toasty then dry finish. Good but much prefer brandy barrel sweetness and even the base beer over this.
At Mikkeller Bar in San Francisco with Taylor. allies brown murky. Aroma is fit raison sticky sweetness. Taste is thick charred caramel, raison fig. Really nice smooth fireside sipper.
2013 sampled back-to-back with a 2011 Brandy which I found to be even better. Not that this ones bad! Lots of caramel, dark fruit and no shortage of bourbon.

2013 purchased in 04/15 and dranked. I think I paid a stupid amount for this, but it was dammm good. aroma is layered caramel, but also oakey bourbon is in there. whiskey looking pour. 5 for palate - not sludgy thick, but solid. Taste is great. caramel, figs, some brown sugars and a good alcohol burn finish. liked this better colder as it warms the alcohol would over power.

2009 bottle. Appearance is muddy brown with white head. Wonderful aroma of dates, caramel, oak, and bourbon. Taste is light oak, caramel, vanilla,  tobacco, and some oxidized cardboard taste. Medium bodied and carbonation, surprisngly smooth finish. Overall this is pretty tasty, that being said I think I waited a bit too long on this one as some oxidation is seeping in, still good though.

Tasted the 2013 CR on 4-8-2015 
Color - Brownish with a red hues. 
Nose - Incredible. The perfect balanced aroma of a great Ale and Stout, with rich dark fruits, cocoa, toasted coconut, and oak. 
Taste - Medium body with still a lovely carbonation. Not very boozy feeling at 14.1% and the bitterness I found on the regular OSA is gone. Theres a ton of dried fruits up front (raisins, prunes and dried figs), with chocolate and a hint of toasted coconut at the mid palate and rum soaked oak chips on the finish as well as a lightly buttered toast to chew on. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2013 pours reddish brown with a cream colored head. Aroma of brown sugar, bourbon, dark fruits and tobacco. Taste follows nose.

Tap at Steins in mountain view. Thick, caramel color, creamy foam. Caramel milk chocolate, figs in the nose, not super distinguished though. A little hot on the tongue but very little relative to the ABV. Flavor is as described above but a roast bitterness commiserates with bourbon alcohol. Tad dry. Really great.

2013 at Steins 2nd Anniversary! Dark fruit, molasses and alcohol combine smoothly on the nose. Rustic hazy brown with white head. Complex fruit and layers of malt - molasses, bread, dough. Alcohil is hidden behind the flavor but crept in as it warmed. Smooth sherry finish that is moderately dry for the alcohol. Wonderful.

2013 bottle. Smells like vanilla and caramel with bourbon. Taste with layers of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, toffee and smokey oak. Delicious all around beer, gets better as it warms, definitely a sipper.

Bottle. Murky brown pour with a small head that bubbles away to nothing quickly. Rich, burnt caramel, toffee, vanilla, and bourbon. Big, boozy bourbon taste makes this a sipper. Big burnt caramel and toffee sweetness helps to balance. More oak as it warms. Medium to full body. Great sipper but I enjoyed the brandy one more.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2017 Bottle (500ml $25): 2013: Brown with thin tan head. Aroma of whisket and sweetness. Taste is sweet caramel and whiskey with some warming. Great sipper.  Update 03/07/2017: vintage 2013.  Very good, very expensive.  Maybe the best barrel age barley wine I have had. Was 4.1.

2009 bottle thanks to Adam! Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is apple skin, caramel, bourbon, and butterscotch. Slick mouthfeel, nice bourbon, vanilla, candy sugar, wood, lingering sweetness, really enjoyed this one.
Draft pour at Sidedoor. Carmel toffee and candy aroma. Red cloudy and dark pour, no head. Taste is carmel, bourbon, toffee, and very sweet. Delicious

Bottled. 2013 vintage. Pours dark chestnut, almost murky brown, with a fairly prominent off-white head. Aroma is lots of bourbon, toffee, fig, sweet candied fruits. Flavor is bourbon, very sweet fruits, fig, raisin. Body is fairly effervescent for such a strong beer, but its welcome and actually really nice. Slightly bitter finish which makes it better. Fantastic beer.
finally get to try this one. The age ddid it well. Doesnt taste oxidized at all. Nice complex molasses flavor profile. Good bourbon flavors, tasty.

Pours a beautiful clear dark amber. Minimal to no head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of cotton candy toffee caramel corn subtle amount of booze. Starts malty sweet then followed by hints of burnt sugar and bourbon notes. The vanilla flavors from the barrel aging are prominent and add to the beer. Mouthfeel is medium plus. Overall excellent dessert beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from WLV. Poured quite dark hazy brown purple light carb med bod. Sweet boozy caramel toffee. Light carb med bod. Taste sweet prune oak grape.
UPDATED: MAY 2, 2015 Smell is bourbon and malt. Taste is sweet malt, bourbon, honey, and caramel. Medium sharp carbonation with medium to full body.

Yummy! The barrel aging takes Old Stock Ale up a couple of noches and its really delicious. At at $20 a bottle you question the value but without a doubt I will purchase another on payday. Well worth the price and as I said earlier, yummy!

Bottle. Pours hazy brown with red hues and off-white head. Aroma prunes, figs, bourbon, vanilla, touch of wood, brown sugar. Taste medium to full bodied, rich, great bourbon taste-nothing overly but a really nice touch, medium carbonation. Overall, very nice.

Bottle, 2013 label. Pours a cloudy and very dark brown color with a moderate light tan head on there. Nose is extremely rich and satisfying with old wood and hints of whiskey overlaying a bit of caramel. Taste has some sweet hints of caramel and butterscotch, and has a smooth woody finish. I feel like I should be drinking this in an old bar with lots of dark wood and dim lighting.

2013 label (January 2015 release) 500ml bottle. Flat, murky brown pour. Aroma is bourbon, touch of sweet dark fruit. Taste is caramel, vanilla, bourbon. Malty. Slightly boozy but very easy to drink. Other than the price, $23 for a 500ml, I have nothing to complain about.
500 ml. bottle. Pours a somewhat cloudy reddish gold with an average tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and fruit. Taste is caramel malt, bourbon, dark fruit, and vanilla. Nice to sip on.

Shared 16.9 oz. bottle poured to snifters, displaying a hazed, amber color, with only a light layer of off white film, light spots of lacing, and a syrupy sheen on the glass when swirled. The nose was alcohol at the ready, dark fruit as plum & raisin, and barrel induced vanilla & coconut. The taste revealed the booziness of the bourbony alcohol, caramel sweetness, with moderate carbonation, in a medium+ body. A smooth & warming, benchmark brew to relax with.

Bottle, 2009. Pours cloudy hazel, minimal head, a touch of lacing. Aroma is rich vanilla bourbon toffee. Flavor is quite sweet, some oxidation but rich malty bourbon vanilla. Medium body, lightly acidic.
Amber pour, no head, looks flat. Very fizzy mouthfeel though. Watery as it warms. Nose and taste is candi sugar and light bourbon barrel.

Bottle to glass. 2013 vintage. Pours a medium nut brown with reddish hues and a light tan head. Aroma is big vanilla, light bourbon, molasses. Big vanilla in the flavor as well, with a solid malt backbone, molasses, gooey. Thick creamy body with a lingering vanilla and light bourbon character in the finish. Quite tasty!

This was pretty darn amazing. Easy to drink for a 14.1% beer, it has all of the great qualities of the traditional Old Stock, with a slightly mellower feel and a hint of the bourbon char as well. I wish it wasnt so darn expensive, but thats really the only knock. A great beer to sign off with for a little while.

Poured from newest vintage, I believe 2014, so is this unretired considering its on the shelf right now? Pours a murky brownish red with a thin head, the aroma has quite a bit of bourbon and vanilla with a strong amount of dark fruits and sweetness, the flavor has a nice bourbon front end with a finish of dark fruit and malt, nice.
Bottle shared. 2009. Pours a hazy brown with beige head. Aroma and taste of caramel, booze, wood, with hints of vanilla. Very nice.

Bottle, Vertical tasting with 2014 old stock, 2012 ostuchi, 2011 Brandy, 2009 Bourbon. All pour similar murky brown with the BA versions being fairly low carb. Aroma is dark fruits, light oak and bourbon, smooth booze and rich malts.

2009 vintage in ceramic grey bottle. Pours a murky brown with minimal white lacy head. Aroma of heavy bourbon vanilla sweetness. Taste is more balanced toward the malt, but still big bourbon notes. Little to no carbonation, sweet and boozy, but nice.

Vintage 2009 bottle purchased and poured at The Porter Bar in Atlanta on 11/23/14. Pours deep dark brown with no head at all. Beautiful aroma of vanilla, caramel, lots of smooth bourbon still present, oak, toffee, marshmallow. Flavor follows with a big bourbon punch that is very mellow, sweet brown sugar and caramel, vanilla marshmallow notes, a hint of chocolate, smooth oak. Wow this is good. Chewey body with low plus carbonation, coats the mouth. This was really nice and the bottle was clearly well-kept for the past few years. Just a really nice beer.

Bottle (375 ml). 2009 vintage. Slightly hazy dark ruby with a small ring of beige foam. Aroma is quite complex with bourbon, figs, plums, raisins, vanilla, molasses, alcohol, oxidation notes, oak and hints of tobacco. Taste is not really sweet, which is nice... but it didnt held up as good as the aroma. Theres bourbon, molasses, tobacco, vanilla, plums, figs, raisins and alcohol. Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Viscous and syrupy mouthfeel. Warming (but not burning) finish. Very elegant Barrel-Aged Barley Wine! Quite complex and nice depth. Aroma is entincing. Completely different than the regular Old Stock, which tell a lot about how good are these guys with barrels.

2009, bottle pour at CK. Syrupy mahogany pour, almost no head. Nose and flavor were rife with molasses, marzipan, caramel, still some boozy heat, huge malt complexity. Rich, but not cloying or overbearing. Really nice stuff.

2009 vintage. Among the best barley wines Ive had. Pours clear mahogany with good head and lacing. Not so syrupy but thick. Smells like a lot of barrel on initial whiff but comes together with good balance afterwards. Some caramel, booze is well-hidden. Great stuff. Bottle pour at Churchkey -- thanks to Jackl for a taste of this.

Bottle @ CK. deep brown with no head. Strong bourbon. Vanilla and toffee. Some raisin and cocoa. The flavors a beautiful representation of tasteful barrel treatment. Holy shit. Perfect vanilla and hot cross buns. Rich, thick caramel malt notes. Slight heat on the finish. Full body, soft carb. So excellent.

"nuts, wood, caramel, dark fruit...whiskey and butterscotch. the hops even show themselves just a little, making this an incredibly smooth, complex sipper. i cant say i like it better than the Raspy 12...and definitely not 9x as good as Old Stock, though it costs more than 2 four packs of the base brew. that said, it was worth it for a bottle...and since this was a split bottle, i still got one more."
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a reddy brown color without much head. Malty and mild bourbon balances well.

2009 bottle. muddy brown with a small but persistent beige head and some lively bubbles arising from the murky depths. oaky woody aroma with caramel and hints of vanilla. lots of sweet caramel and vanilla with oak and bourbon. more carbonated than usual for this sort of thing to my surprise. the co2 level however distracts slightly from the complex flavor. its a good beer, but not worth the heavy pricetag. i remember sampling the brandy barrel years ago and remember it as superior.

2009 ed. Drank as the tail end of a 5 year regular Old Stock. This was one hell of rich drink. Low carbonation delivered smooth bourbon and rich caramel. Closer to a cordial than a beer. Rich, boozy, but subdued to the 5 years of age. A sipper for sure.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2014 Murky brown color with tan head. Aroma is molasses, dried figs, oak, and whiskey. Flavor is malty with molasses and figs. Some nice oak flavors in the middle with caramel and brown sugar flavors and finishing with a whiskey booziness.

Dark brown with thin head. Vanilla oak molasses and booze aroma. Slightly sticky sweet molasses and dried fruit flavors. Five years has made this barlt wine very smooth, still has enough carbonation. A very nice treat from the wife.

2009 version. Ruby brown, initial pale head that dissipated quickly. Aroma is brown sugar, dark fruits, hint of marshmallow and vanilla. Medium bodied, slightly sticky mouthfeel, sweet on the palate. Flavours are raisins, dates, prunes, figs, brown sugar, marshmallow. Delicious

Sampled at the RBSG14 Grand Tasting - Pours tawny brown with an off-white head. The aroma has caramel, bourbon, toffee and rich malt. It has a full rich body with light carbonation. It starts off with caramel, booze, berries, rich malt and barrel notes. The finish adds a lot of vanilla and bourbon. Nice and has held up well.
Pours a deep amber with no head. Malty syrupy sweet aroma. Maple notes with a clear boziness that lingers.
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Bourbon, sweet aromas. Flavor is sweet malt, bourbon and oak tones.

2005 and 2009 opened beside each other. Caramelized malts, melted sugars mixed with bourbon, mild boozy profile massages my throat after I swallow. Bit more bourbon in the '05 than the '09, yet both are excellent. I dig.

50cl, at 13.16%Vol, as Old Stock Cellar Reserve 2009 Aged in Bourbon Barrels, exclusive American brew, thx alot to Dirk for sharing!, very complex brew, alcoholic/woody and slightly sweet/fruity, yet not too heavy, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!, WOW!, "Less heavy than the Brandy edition, this sample aged very well!"

Bottle. Pours ruby red/brown with a small tan head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel and toffee. Flavor was slightly sweet with caramel, raisins, vanilla, bourbon, oak, dark fruit, and had a nice dry warming alcohol finish. Medium body, light carbonation, syrupy texture.
2009 bottle pours a hazy brown with a tan head. Big caramel and bourbon oak aroma. Bourbon vanilla syrup and sweet malt taste.
Deep brown pour, small white head. Big aroma of fruit roast and toffee, flavor is complex, alcohol chocolate, dark fruit, toffee, figs. Whoa.

Pour - deep brown. No head. 

Aroma - caramel and cookies

Mouth - velvet 

Taste - hints of toffee and booze. Really balanced. Might be the smoothest BBA I have had. Bourbon shows through in a good way. 

Overall - this beer is really balanced and amazing.

500 ML bottle bought at Apex in Portland

Dark mahogany color with a fast fading off white head that sits at a collar. 
Nose is bourbon, brown sugar, vanilla, and fig. Not nearly as sweet and sticky as the brandy version. 
Taste is oak, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate and fig. 
Medium bodied, light carbonation. Not sweet, sticky, or port like as the brandy version was. Much more reserved and slightly thinner. Still brilliant though
Drar parallellt bot en Brandy-variant. Årgång 2009. Kraftig bourbon i doften. Lite spritig men ton av champinjon. Positivt oxiderad. Söt och lite nötig men otippat tunn. Inget som stör dock.

Bottle @ Steves Super Bowl party. Pours a cloudy orangish brown appearance with a fizzy brown head. Heavy caramel and chocolate aroma. Some oak and whiskey as well. Dessert nose. Not nearly as sweet or goopy flavor as the brandy release. Booze is held in check a lot better. Fair amount of sweetness but not overwhelming. This was much more enjoyable and drinkable to me then the brandy version. Potentially a touch muted but good.

Pour is translucent brown with a small tan head. Aroma is heavy on the bourbon with notes of oak, vanilla, and caramel. Flavor is moderately sweet with the booze and bourbon coming through the strongest. Syrupy with little carbonation.
Most boozy of the bunch vs sucaba and bcntybw. Although 3rd of this bunch still great.
Pours reddish with clouds of whispy head. Aroma and taste of coconut and cremé brulee. The best barleywine Ive had to date.
#5000. 2009vintage. shimmery sherry looking pour. bourbon/whiskey, toffee richness. definite sipper. rich, boozy, delicious

Bottle to teku, dark red brown body with a thin light head that dissipates quickly. Nose is sweet Bourbon, raisins, toffee. Taste is a sweet raisiny, caramel, toffee, Bourbony boozy burn. Really smooth.

09 edition.

Havent really taken the time to review this, although Ive had it probably six or seven times before; I usually only open one with company and dont wanna be rude and review in front of them. This time - the bottle is allll mine!

Pours a nice amber with a fleeting finger of taupe foam - leaving an etched surface. Nose is immaculate - nougat, bourbon, vanilla, fine malt syrup, bits of toffee, some caramalized sugar (near true creme brulee toasting). Flavor is rich and decadent with some maple, bourbon, vanilla, rich malts, some really nice sugars and a caramel flavor. Medium bodied with prickly carbonation. I really dig this beer.

Serving type: bottle

12-03-2012

2009 bottle from a free beer contest. many thanks to who sent me this, i forget. bottle opens with a pop. pours mahogany amber with little head. raisins, toffee, caramel, vanilla, smokey bourbon, oak all wrapped in a big body with some mild booze burn. awesome.

2009 bottle. Dark brown/copper pour with a small light tan head. Aromas of oak, vanilla, and caramel. Dark fruits on the palate with toffee notes. This has aged really well! Abv is noticeable at first but as it warms up a bit it mellows out nicely. Great brew!

2009 bottle, pours nice reddish brown with khaki fizz, still looking alright after 4 years. Great aroma of sweet lightly roasted barley giving way to big toasted oak and vanilla. The flavor is ridiculous, immediately satisfying. Very smooth grains with a light sweetness that doesn?t show too much heat or lasting susugaryness helped by some caramel flavors and a light accent on dark tree fruits. A great balance brought in by the oak with just a hint of bourbon and lingering rich vanilla and wood character. Still a big beer but extremely well done. Having split a bottle, I just had to cherish my pour. Probably about as good as it will get after 4 years.
Bottle. From notes. Boozy witha hint of oak. Bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar and dark fermented fruits. Awesome .

2009 vintage, Brandons house, split 3 ways. Thanks, Ryan. Pours deep golden orange. Aroma of oak, bourbon and vanilla. Taste is barleywine, caramel, bourbon, vanilla. I wish I could remember this better at that point in the night, but it was fantastic.
Great. Huge beer. Had at 28 Springs in a bottle. Slight alcohol notes but caramel and malt comes through. Nice.

2009 vintage. Pours a rich copper brown color with a finger of eggshell foam. Round sweet maple, molasses, toasted vanilla and sticky dates. The mouthfeel is soft and velvety with a drying finish that nicely contrast the soft front end. Big caramel notes on the palate with complex sweetness that creeps from maple waffles to sugar cones and toasted oak. YUM !

2009 Vintage
1/12/2011: North Coast Old Stock Ale 2009 Cellar Reserve Bourbon... Aroma: Sugary rye bourbon; alcohol-soaked golden raisin; dates; alcohol Appearance: Hazelnut color, transparent; thin beige ring of foam. Flavor: Tons of awesome vanilla; hints of barrel char and walnut; caramelized sugar; boozy; tobacco through the finish; lots of alcohol through the nose. Palate: Medium-bodied; smooth. Overall: Damn great beer; a fantastic treatment of Old Stock Ale.
1 pt, 0.9 fl. oz. (500 ML) corked and caged bottle (Alcc/Vol. 13.16%) shared by Tmoney99. Thanks Tom! Rating #364 for this beer.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 2009 vintage. It pours a murky brown with a thin but active off white head. The head is gone fairly quickly, but there is still a good bit of tiny bubbles popping up to the surface. The nose is blows you back with notes of fig, dark caramel, bourbon, light wood, and vanilla. The flavor is equally powerful. Lots of caramel, toffee, fig, date, bourbon, and vanilla. The flavor just goes on and on, evolving as it warms. Long, warming finish. Dangerous ABV, but perfect for sipping as a night cap.

Just awesome. 2009 vintage poured dark murky brown with an off white head. Smell is bourbon, brown sugar, and hazelnut. Taste is amazing! Nice roasted almond with fig, brown sugar, and vanilla, with of course the perfect amount of bourbon in the background. Medium carbonation and perfect mouth feel. Really good.

Bottle. Dark amber beer with a beige head. Dark fruits, whiskey, vanilla, caramell, malty, almonds, fruity, coconuts and nutty aroma. Malty, almond, whiskey, vanilla, oaky, dark fruits and nutty flavour. Love in a bottle :-)

500 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you! Pours clear deep copper with a thin fizzy golden head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is intense, sweet, fruity and malty with caramel, biscuits, toffee, bourbon, tons of raisins but also figs and dates, vanilla fudge, charred American oak, burning and tingling alcohol, caramelized almonds, roasted hazelnuts, coconut shells, brazil nuts, dried papaya, sweet dark bread, high quality sherry and hints of Christmas fruitcake. Taste is slightly sweet, tiny bitter, malty and fruity with sweet dark bread, raisins, figs, dates, bourbon, sherry, moist wood, vanilla fudge, toffee, brazil nuts, caramelized almonds, hay, alcohol and biscuits. Mouthfeel is tiny round, boozy, slightly dry and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, tiny bitter and slightly fruity tart with caramel, vanilla fudge, moist wood, raisins, dates, hay, charred wood, roasted nuts, sherry and hints of tart cherries and dry sparkling wine. Amazing smell supported by a great taste. Only thing I feel is lacking is a rounder smoother mouthfeel.Actually rolling the beer around in the mouth a little really helps the mouthfeel. Very tasty...

From a bottle at the mark dine and tap in south bend IN. Vintage 2009.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a thin, quickly disappearing head.  Sweet caramel aroma.  Complex nutty flavor with muted sweet caramel and candy sugar.  Warming alcohol finish.  A really exceptional barley wine.

Bottle 375ml. @ Tasting by Benzai [ ZZT V ].Clear medium to dark red brown colour with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, malty, alcohol - bourbon, licorice - laber larver, plum. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, vintage - wood, bourbon - laber laver, alcohol. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20121006]

Pius a deep golden orange. Aroma of oak, bourbon and vanilla. Taste is bourbon and vanilla, very smooth very tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ceramic bottle compliments of Joe, this beer is freaking great! Pours deep brown with medium creamy head and not much lacing. Aromas and flavor of heavy, buttery bourbon. Smaller notes of dark fruit, smooth malt, vanilla, and tons of rich wood. Medium to fuller body. Heat was restrained. This is right on par with Angels Share. Top Notch
Bottle of 2009 for #2700. Hazy dark amber with a tan head. Scent is sweet malts, wood and booze. Taste is sweet, real sweet, with bourbon, caramel and wood.
2009 vintage. The complexity is insane. Vanilla, maple, walnut, waffles, caramel, with an incredibly soft yet warming mouth feel. One of the best beers Ive ever had.
2009 on 2/3/13 - still brandy looks. Amazing walnut, ice cream cone, vanilla nose. Tawny port city, a little tongue numbness, sweet tea, waffles, sugar, heat.

2009 Bottle.  Pours lightly murky brown with a small, fizzy light tan head, mostly clings and dissipates to the edges, short retention with no particular lacing.  Aroma is lightly oxidized caramel and cookie malt, some cork/paper notes with light sherry aromas floating about, brown sugar, dates, figs, plums, fresh oak, vanilla, and bourbon with spicy hops.  Flavor is sweet malt with oak, dark fruity esters, vanilla, bourbon, spicy alcohol with light hops and bitterness and a sweet yet drying finish.  Full body and medium-light carbonation.

Pours a dark black with a decent caramel head developing.  Head dissipates quickly to a small ring collecting around the glass.  Big vanilla and toffee up front in the aroma with hints of homemade caramel.  Tastes of vanilla cocoa with undertones of bourbon shining through. Very clean beer with minimal residual flavor lasting too long on the palate. Over all the is a top notch barrel aged stout.
Gedronken tijdens ZztV, bruin helder, beige schuim, ruikt naar barrel aged, beetje fruitig, zoet,

This bourbon barrel aged cork & caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a softly carbonated hazy brown colored body and a oily lacing. The strong aroma was vinous alcohol and bourbon.  The aromas strong alcohol content took my breath away.  he semi-flat mouth feel was very tingly at the start and at the finish vinous aftertaste. The overwhelmingly vinous flavor contained notes of old ale vinous alcohol and malt. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2015 2012.12.26 - 500ml bottle of 2009 in small goblet.   I really enjoy regular Old Stock Ale, so this was kind of a no brainer and I bought 3 bottles knowing one would cellar and one would be tasted almost immediately.   Pours a mid-opaque raisin-y, caramel-y medium tan.  Little head despite having reasonable carbonation.  A mild ring is fed by bubbles from the bottom.  Aroma is sweet candied fruit, plum/raisin/date sort of starchy sweetness.  Taste follows that, adds a bit of alcohol warmth, but not much given 13%+ abv. A bit vanilla, a bit bourbon.  Its surprisingly, dangerously smooth.  Mouthfeel is slick and a bit creamy.  Really good stuff.  Hard to imagine this aging anything less than very well.  Quintessential yummy high alcohol long term storage bang-for-buck old ale / barley wine, down to the bottle design.  Ill be grabbing more of these.

2015.03.02-had a bottle of 2013 vintage, great, very smooth.

2009 vintage in the gray ceramic bottle served in a snifter.  Dark brown cola pour.  Surprising amount of carbonation for the age under a cork.  An off white head fades quickly but a gentle swirl brings the dense, consistent foam top right back for a moment.  Aroma is maple, oak, and bourbon.  Its got the same aroma as Utopias or Triple Bock.  I had this in 2009 upon the release audit was a luxurious, boozy, elixir. This is still good but Im sad to say that at this age its lost a lot of the body and sweetness I recall from before.  The flavor is more oak than beer and the palate is very thin.  Alcohol heat remains but this drinks much more like a whiskey than a beer.  I wish I had opened this one sooner.

2009 bottle. Pours deep brown with no head. Aroma is heavy bourbon with a lot of vanilla and woody notes. Dried figs, caramel, cake, prunes within, as well as an alcohol presence. Taste is massive - huge maltiness combined with a huge bourbon presence. We got dried fruits, muscavado sugar, cake crust, some sharp alcohol in combination with the bourbon notes - vanilla, oak and a hint of coconut. The alcohol is necessary in a beer this strong, and it is actually quite balanced. Very nice!

Thank you SJ for this one. Best beer of the week.

An amazing aroma of caramel, oak, with a dark fruit ester. Flavor was burnt malts, raisin, caramel malts,  wood, vanilla and nuts. It had a perfect blend and the bourbon warmed as it went down.

23/11/12 - 50cl bottle @ home - BB: n/a (2012-1303) Thanks to otakuden for the trade!
Clear red brown beer, small off-white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: wow, amazing! Lots of milk chocolate, caramel, vanilla, sweet, fudge, milk chocolate. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: pretty sweet start, caramel, fudge, chocolate, (yoghurt covered) raisins, vanilla, some alcohol. Aftertaste: chocolate, fudge, caramel, bit sweet.

2009 bottle, 12/3/2012. Pours rich chestnut brown, thin fizzy head fades within a minute or so, light ring of lacing. Aroma is decidedly barrel dominated, but wonderfully done: vanilla caramel bread pudding, fruity raisin malt character, dosed with chocolate, smooth bourbon and wood. Alcohol not noticeable. Taste of subtle dark fruits, brown sugar caramel, big vanilla and toffee, bourbon notes in a woody, nutty dry finish. Medium thick palate, remains smooth and drinkable despite the ABV. Wow, quite nice, much better with a few years of age than at release.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2012 2009 vintage. @ Novare Res. this beer is so comes in both nose and taste it is silly. Not kidding. Ridiculous! Nose is dark fruit, raisins, candy sugar, vanilla oak. Every time I smell and taste this ;I get a different variety of flavors and aromas. Texture is vinous, kind of like a flat cognac. Hennessy like in texture. This is magic in a bottle. Changes with each sip. Complexity is off the chain here, (not to sound like an old thug) But truly amazing on every level.

Shared bottle at craft ale house. Pours hazy copper with no head. The aroma Is bourbon as can be with some malt sweetness in the distance. The taste is very bourbon forward with some sweet malt in the distance.

Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Deep amber beer with a nice small but lasting beige head. Aroma from toffee, almonds, prunes, vanilla, biscuits, hazelnuts, warming alcohol, cream, figs, raisins, woody, whisky, dades, caramel, fudge, toffee notes. Malty flavor, quite a lot of warming alcohol, almonds, whisky, vanilla, figs, raisins, woody, fudge, caramel, dades, hazelnuts, prunes. Finish brings warming alcohol, fudge, caramel, almonds, figs and raisins. Very good!

Bottle 50 cl, tnx to Greg. Pours clear ruby brown with a small rim of head. Aroma is vinous acidy slightly sour vanilla dill bourbon fruity cocoa raisins fidges caramel. Flavor is vinous boozy raisins grapes fidges malty pungent bitter tinglybon tounge vanilla barrel slightly dry. Finishes dry fruity raisins and bitter with good warming alcohol touch.
Poured dark brown with no real head smelled of bourbon and licorice....tasted about the same with less bourbon.  Decent beer

Ruby red colour, slight white head. Aroma of wood, caramel, madeira, raisins, bourbon, vanilla and alcohol. Light sweet flavour, caramel, raisins, over-ripe fruits and alcohol. Quite cloying sweet, but in a sort of dessert wine way.
Very interesting and nice. Wouldnt want to drink a whole bottle of this, but served in small quantities it is quite lovely.
(From 50cL bottle @ ZZT V. 2009 vintage. Courtesy of joes. Thanks!!)

Yes! Pours dark brown with bubbly white head. Aroma is dark fruits, slightly acidic, vanilla, alcohol, spicy. Taste is sweet, spicy, sour, hot, thick, wonderful, busy. No lacing. Delicious. This was really amazing. Its understandably expensive but is worth the price.

Bottle shared by jayhawk73. Thanks Jeff!

2009 vintage

The beer is a crimson / brown / ruby color, with just a fleeting glimpse of a head. The aroma is simply fabulous. Delectable bourbon, oak, malt. Perfect blend of flavors. This beer tastes amazing. Incredibly smooth, time has served this old ale very well. The $20+ price tag is a bit steep, but wow, this beer delivers. Alcohol presence is completely unobtrusive. I highly recommend this beer. A must try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-25-2011

500 ml C&C bottle served in a Founders tulip. 2009 Cellar Reserve.

A: Pours a semi translucent deep brown and ruby combination with a light tan head forming on the pour. It recedes quickly to a thin ring. No real lace left down the glass, but there are some nice legs.

S: This smells incredible. It is barrel forward with some charred oak, smooth bourbon, and semi-sweet caramel. Dark fruits, mostly raisin, but a touch of fig newton is also present. As it warms more of the bourbon comes out in the nose with a touch of alcohol.

T: Lots of great flavors going on. Definite oak character with some bourbon, residual vanilla and a definite caramel sweetness. Toffee with some fig and sweet malts. There is a slight nutty quality to it as well and it blends with the overall sweetness nicely. There is some definite heat hitting the back of the throat, but its a subtle warming which is very nice. 

M: Medium to full bodied with a medium/low carbonation level. A touch of warming down throat greets each sip. 

O: This is a great sipper. I smelled this forever before I finally took a drink. I enjoyed this one immensely and it is definitely in the top five old ales Ive ever had. The barrel is nicely integrated and helps create another layer of flavor that definitely compliments the base beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-22-2012

500ml bottle from Binnys Plainfield. 2009 Vintage. Pours a cloudy, deep brown colored body with a bit of an amber hue. Finger-width, frothy, brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is big oak and bourbon up front before a nice, sweeter caramel comes in. Some vanilla, dark fruits, maple, brandy, and a bit of a vinous note. Flavor is similar. Big oak, vanilla, and bourbon up front before a nice, dark caramel and toffee comes in. A light vinous note again with some prune dark fruits, maple, brandy, and a touch of cocoa coming out in the end. Finishes mostly dry and somewhat sweet with a light alcohol note and a big, woody bourbon and vanilla aftertaste that lingers for a lengthy duration. Mostly full body that is a bit thinned by the barrel aging and a light, soft carbonation. Overall, a big, but really well done barley wine. Plenty of malts, but loads of wood, bourbon, and vanilla to balance and keep this from being cloying or extremely sweet; pretty great barrel aging. Highly enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours dark red-brown, clear and quickly disappearing head. Aroma of bourbon/whisky, sweet vanilla, roasted, mocha/toffee and sweet alcohol. On the sweet side with upcoming roasted bitterness. Bourbon, toffee, alcohol, raisins in taste.

Bottle pours a darker orange close to brown huge head lots of carb. Surprised by how much was in there bubbles kept flowing from bottom of glass. Fantastic look. Smell and taste amazing. Caramel bourbon semi hot. Sweet dark fruits brien sugar molasses. Good mix Id say couldnt get much better seems to have mixed bit still all flavors alive and kicking. I may buy a few more this is good shit. My kind of barly wine. Screw hops in them I want booze and caramel.

Dark copper body and beige lace. Red grapes, raisins, eathy and concentrated fruit. Strong wood and dark fruit taste, some warmth. Flavourful and powerful, enough balancing hops. Very nice, excellent. (At ZZT V)
2009 bottle @ ZZT V. Thanks to Joes. Great dark red color, no head. Smell and taste malts, bourbon, sweetness, wood. Great beer! Full body, medium to full carbonation.
@ZZT V. Copper brown colour with no head. Smells heavily sweet, lots of wood, malts, hazelnut. Tastes sweet, wood, hazelnut, lots of taste. Quite nice.Thick feel, full body, very soft carbo.

Acquired at Hunger Mountain Co-Op in March. I believe this was priced at about $30. Enjoyed at Cellar temp in a snifter. 

A - 2-finger slight tan head was produced but faded almost instantly. Very solid alcohol legs on the glass. Sort of a dark brown, hint of amber and plum appearance. 

S - Hint of sweetness and minor maltiness on the nose. Its a very unsuprisingly unsweet scent for a barleywine. Then again, this is an aged beer so perhaps this isnt too surprising. Smokey oak and Bourbon and present but very smooth and not over boozy. The nose overall has a great balance. 

T - This is incredibly hard to describe. First, I get some dark fruits like figs and cherries. Followed by a minor sweetness and hint of delicate vanilla bourbon whiskey. The sweetness is a mix of simple syrup and brown sugar. I love that theres this caramel and candy like taste at the finish. 

M - This coats the tongue and numbs it. Its a mouth numbing beer that has a sort of orajel like feeling when it numbs things. Very heavy body, slick oily texture and vanilla sweetness finish. 

O - This may be one of the finest barley wines Ive ever had. Its incredible and exceptional in so many ways. Its hard to not give this beer a 5.

3rd May 201014.6% Version. Cloudy dark brown beer, no head. Light fresh sea breeze nose with a whisper of bourbon. Light palate, crisp and woody - dry. Sweet vanilla bourbon. Minerally mid and then dry creamy licorice with a little spice. Finishes dry. Obviously a strong beer but it doesnt present much alcohol heat. Delightful if a tad dry.

(500ml bottle) Courtesy of Irishboy... Thanks Richard! Crazy strong fig concentrate. Smooth vanilla body, wood barrel, raisin purée and spice. Incredibly intense. Thanks R!

--- reviewed on RateBeer.com

2009 vintage.  Thin head of rather large bubbles from a vigorous pour.  Excellent carbonation eminating from the mark in the bottom of my glass.  Very unusual to have a barleywine with this much carbonation, especially after 3 years.  Amazing aroma loaded with butterscotch, bourbon, sweet malts, dried apricots and caramel.  Color is a murky mahagony brown.  Big bourbon presence in the flavor.  Lots more butterscotch, sweet malts, caramel and some rum soaked raisins.  Noticable alcohol presence and warming but does not detract from such a strong flavor.  Mouthfeel is loaded with chewey malts.  They took a fantastic barleywine and put a little twist on it that makes it just as good if not better then the original.  Nice job!
2009 bottle..Nose is Vanilla, chocolate, whiskey, wood, coffee..Taste is brown sugar, wood, chocolate, vanilla, whiskey, sweetness..Nice very well balance and boldness

2009 bottle...Pours an opaque amber/brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is boozy with bourbon notes...fig and candied fruits.  Flavor has great vanilla and bourbon atop candied fruits...not as boozy or sweet as the aroma.  Mouthfeel is full and the finish warms with fruity/bourbon notes and a touch of oak.

[4329-20120311] Corked bottle. Meaty vegetable stock and toasted malt aroma. Murky, brown roan red body with a very quick foamy off-white head. Toasted hearty vegetable soup malt continues in the flavour with oak wood hints and a sweet barrelly finish. Full body. Tasty, good balance between the barreling and the boozing. (8-/3/8/4/16) 3.9
(w/ jerc)

500mL corked and caged bottle, 2009 vintage.  Pours lively dark orange, super-dark orange and garnet red in the glass, with a fizzy tan head that fizzes away to nothing quite quickly.  Aromas of grape juice, cocoa, raisin, and alcohol.  Malty, fruity, and sweet.  Light buttered toast and jam, with some toffee notes, become evident as it warms.  The flavor is sweet raisin and prune and plum, buttered toast, and buttery oak with very light bourbon.  Somewhat boozy finish with buttery oak and toast and jam, and light vanilla.  Low to medium carbonation, medium to full body, dry, and a bit hot.  Tasty, with very subtle bourbon.  A nice sipper.  [996]

Corked and caged  2009 bottle.  Rated on 3-26-2012.  Pours a large tan fizzy head that quickly diminished.  There was no lacing, hazy body and a reddish hue.  The Aroma is caramel, sweet, brown sugar, suggestions of dark fruit, oak, and bourbon.  The Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, caramel, some oak, and bourbon.  The Mouthfeel is very tingly along with a warming sensation from the bourbon.  This is a medium bodied Barley Wine.  Barley Wine is not one of my favorite beer styles; however, that being said, I REALLY enjoyed sipping on this one.  Yes, it is a sipper at 13.7%ABV.  The Aromas and Flavors come together very nicely making this a Barley Wine well worth trying and one that I would definitely drink again.

2012-03-11. Murky brown body, small beige head fades. Aroma is sweet and fairly alcoholic, sugars, caramel malt notes, hints at bourbon. Simple but rich. Alcohol becomes more prominent as it warms a bit. 7+ Flavour is similar, sweet malty core, light bitterness around the edges and modest alcohol presence keep it from becoming cloying. Rich, sweet sugary caramel character, mild wood throughout shows up as mild woody tannins with bourbon overtones in the finish. Medium to full bodied palate is lightly carbonated, alcohol leaves the inside of your mouth just a little bit tingly. 3+ Alcohol is pervasive but not overpowering while its chilled, and is actually fairly restrained considering the alcohol content.  Lovely stuff.  2009 Vintage Bottle, via trade with sprinkle

Bottle. 2009 edition. Thanks Anker for sharing! Pours hazy amber with a small off white head. The aroma is heavy bourbon, dark fruit, molasse, brown sugar, malt and caramel. The flavour is sweet bourbon, malt, sweet caramel, vanilla and brown sugar. Thanks for the sample my friend.

2009 vintage. pours a clear medium to dark orange. nose is canadian whisky with oak, vanilla, stove top hard candy, first sip is sweet with orange, cherry, brandy and sherry qualities. strange almost prickly mouth feel in the beginning. finish is smooth and clean with a great delayed warming feeling.great beer.

Bottle vintage 2009. Pours clear copper with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is lots of bourbon, toffee, vanilla, brown sugar, plums. Flavor is bourbon, vanilla, raisins, wood, sweet tobacco notes, ripe juicy pear. Medium carbonation. Lovely beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Beer was probably my favorite beer of all time.beer has a really sweet aroma and a dark brown appearance. Beer tasted great
I love this beer.Pours brown in color with a medium cream color head.Aroma is good but not overwhelming. Sweet ,creamy with flavors of dates and raisin .

Bottle. [thanks after4ever]
Light murky deep amber with a small, frothy, off-white film head. Aroma has lots of sweet bourbon, light chocolate, fat caramel, plums, vinious. Lowish but prickly carbonation, fat and oily mouthfeel. Flavour is complex, light oxidation, caramel, plums,raisins, vinious, vanilla, sherry. Lovely warming. Lingering light bitter piney and toasted caramel finish. Very nice, but the other version was far better.
Pours a nice amber color.  Good taste, but not great.  I was expecting more, and would almost rather have a regular 2010 Old Stock Ale.  The barrel aging didnt help as much as I was hoping.

Sipped from a snifter slowly to stretch out the experience as long as I could.  The high ABV taste is there, but it is pleasant and warm.  The barrel is also there in the taste, but like the ABV it is a nice accent.  I cant afford to pay $28 for a half-liter very often, but this birthday treat was worth it. I will buy another to put away for my next birthday.
Bottle shared with beerboxer. Great beer. You can taste the bourbon barrel. With a slight alchole flavor. Good beer.
pours a dark gold color with a white fizz. Aroma is of oak and whiskey. Flavor is amazing.I feel like im drinking a vanilla bourbon. Wow its really worth the cost!

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2012 08 on tap at Uber (finally!) Three fingers off white. Murky amber. Strong cherry and vanilla. Slightly boozy. Smooth caramel, spicy, waxy. This is probably my favorite barley wine. Great stuff.
bottle thanks to bman.  poured ruby with no head.  aroma was caramel, bourbon, and sherry with the flavor being much the same.  body was light and slick with little to no carbonation.

500ml bottle from Winooski. 2009 Vintage.
Appearance : Clear dark amber with small head. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Great resinous hops with big fruity notes. Nice vanilla with light raisins. Light oxidation that fits the profile very well.

Taste : Big resinous hops with nice fruits. Notes of vanilla with overcooked caramel. Nice oxidation there too. Light alcohol warmth on the finish but not that much considering the abv. 

Overall : Wow that was good. Very well balanced and mellow. Great hops but not too much. Great malt complexity with the overcooked caramel and the raisins. Very nice balance with the bourbon notes. I dont think its showing any bad signs of aging just yet. One of my top Barley Wines ever.

Bottle at home, from my Maudite glass. Bottle courtesy of jerc, Im fairly sure. Pours clear dark tawny/brown, thin pale tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is big bourbon, raisin, red licorice, anise, vanilla, lots of sweetness and barrel notes here... Flavours of sweet bourbon-raisin, and figgy pudding, loads of toffee and vanilla. Very brandyish in the finish. Pretty much what I expected from this one.

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a dark brown with very little white head. Smells wonderful of bourbon, oak, and brown sugar. Tastes blissful. Very sweet, perhaps a bit much. But superb. Vanilla. Texture is creamy. Medium carbon at; n. Finishes sweet.

2009 Vintage. Aroma is rich, syrupy dark fruits. Raisin, fig, cherry, a touch of strawberry, and then the bourbon notes come in. Murky reddish brown with no head. Flavor is huge. Sweet but warm, balanced. Loads of aforementioned fruit, a good deal of alcohol, oak, vanilla, honey, and a bit of spice. Full, luxurious texture. Heavy but smooth. Restrained depth, without any overwhelming alcohol or sweetness. Short finish but long aftereffects.

A dark rubied brown with a level lasting cover of tan foam.  Aroma is brown sugar, alcohol, bourbon, oak, vanilla, prunes.  Taste is again brown sugar, caramel, prune, plum, candy sweet, the mid palate is oaky, woody, some vanilla, bourbon, not overpowering, then finishes with a slightly thinning alcohol heat and lightly prickly carbonation.
Coconut, bourbon, vanilla on the nose. No head. Tastes bourbon and booze and dark malts. Very good. This is 2009 but I think it will get better with a few more years.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Bottle from Bottle Barn. Holy crap! This beer was the beeâs nuts! Aged Old Stock, sweet barleywine over bourbon. Right up my alley. I drank this one on Xmas eve, and with all the crap going on it shed a little light on the evening. Nice freakin work...outstanding beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Yep.  Im a five whore.  This beer is beer Nirvana.  Along with a couple other pretty much perfect offerings from Fifty Fifty, North Coast, Russian River, and Mikkeller... this one has the same problem... I simply cannot detract from it.  Its awesome.  North Coasts regular Old Stock is perfect in my book (with a year of age on it, fresh, not so much).  This is perfect as well.  It just takes a perfect beer, and make a tasteful tweak that makes it different from the original... but still perfect.  This beer is a caramel, sweet malt, and bourbon orgy in your mouth.  Except its a totally hot chick orgy... and youre on a spaceship, the Niners are winning the Super Bowl, and Pantera is playing in the background.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2012 A - red/brown pour, with high foamy light head. 

S - Strong aromas of bourbon at all times, Nice earthy and smokey oak, toffee and coffee. 

M -no carbonation, with a very heavy body, syrupy. 

T - smokey oaky bourbon on the nose , to a smooth rich vanilla/toffee middle,  to a sweet toffee/coffee finish. Strong boos throughout.

O - Good, well rounded bourbon aged beer. Would be much better if aged.  Boos hold this beer back from being a great beer.

7

500 ml caged and corked bottle, 2009 vintage.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a murky reddish/brown color with about an inch tan cola-like head that fizzled away quickly.  Not much lacing at all.  Aroma is sweet and malty, it smells like dark fruit, caramel, toffee, bourbon, brown sugar and vanilla.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also the addition of some nuts, molasses and a bit of brandy.  Theres also a long lasting sweet malty finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit syrupy and coating with moderate carbonation.  Its also smooth and goes down easy.  I think this is a pretty good overall brew.  Its pricey ($23.99 a bottle), but definitely worth trying.

Pours dark amber with no head at all. The aroma is sweet like brandy with a bit of maple. The flavor is boozy, sweet, less of a body than a normal barleywine without too much resiny sweetness. It is a bit too much personally for my palate, still somewhat smooth for an ABV so high, whiskey notes are there for sure though.
Holy crap.  If you like bourbon beers, this is the best of the best.  Tastes like bourbon lite with great malt undertones.  I love this.

This is more of an after dinner drink than "a cold one."  Its heavy, sweet, complex, and strong.  It is almost an in-between beer and bourbon liquour.  Its unique and very enjoyable.  I wouldnt want it all the time, though.

Bottle. Hazy, deep amber body. Small, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Big aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Full body, velvety texture, moderate carbonation. Big bourbon taste but not enough to mask flavors of dark fruit and vanilla. Peppery alcohol into the finish. Not a big fan of bourbon-dominated beers. Thats the case here, but its really well integrated. Smooth and complex. Nice sipping beer.

I let this warm a bit out of the fridge first. Poured with a smallish tan head that quicly disappeared and no lace. Color is a slightly cloudy amber brown with lots of tiny bubble trails. Aroma is malt, bourbon, raisins, molasses. Flavor is like nose, on the sweet side with a little bitterness and carbonic tang to balance. Body is good, carbonation is fine although light. Finish is like flavor and of average length with a little booziness. Good stuff; however, I expected a little more.

Aroma is heavy on the dark fruit. Sweet figs, plums, and toffee dominate. Pours a brownish amber with a quickly fading foam. Taste is made up of sweet toffees and caramels, vanilla oak, dark fruits, and a dash of bourbon. Lasting finish. Quite nice. One of the better bourbon aged beers as the bourbon is a component rather than the centerpiece.

Bottle, 2009 vintage.  Nutty, woody, sweet and sugary aroma, with milder hints of roast, toffee, vanilla and faint cherry.  Dark red-amber color, the head forming a ring of light tan around the glass.  Sweet, powerful malts dominate the flavor profile, sugary and very lightly roasty, with suggestions of oak, vanilla, toffee, nut, dried fruit and brown sugar.  Not much bourbon character or alcohol is revealed here, surprisingly.  Thick, syrupy mouthfeel, low in effervescence, body is huge, to be sure.  Pretty nice indeed.  Cheers to Amy and John!

bottle. 2009 vintage. translucent, clear dark amber with minimal head. aroma of beautiful oak tannins, vanilla accents, wood, lactose sugars, and butterscotch. decadent and superb. just a touch of alcohol in the back end. flavor of caramelized sugar, milky caramel, oak, and fresh vanilla bean. this is probably the best barley wine i have ever had, and one of the finest examples of beer-making in america. bravo

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Beautiful dark ruby-brown pour with a ring of foam. Aroma is strong bourbon, lots of vanilla, maple syrup, nuts and cream. Taste is great, lots of rich bourbon and vanilla notes, quite sweet, honey and maple flavors are present. A bit of alcohol warmth, but overall pretty well hidden. Body is very heavy, some carbonation helps drinkability greatly. Not an easy beer by per se, but a nice gentle feeling evening sipper.

500 mL bottle from Leukens Dunedin.  Pours a brown with red highlights.  Nose is bourbon, vanilla, toffee, caramel, wood, brandy, and rum-covered raisins.  Flavor is similar.  Miles and miles with layers upon layers.  Bourbon, wood, vanilla, toffee, caramel, raisins, and brandy.  Outstanding BA BW.
Aroma of bourbon oak, flavor is surprisingly sweet and malty, but balanced by the bourbon, alcohol content is shockingly well concealed, excellent beer

500ml bottle in a snifter.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma strong of bourbon, vanilla and oak, roasted and caramel and hints of chocolatey malts, and some floral hops.  Flavor so complex and really strong of bourbon.  Smooth texture, could be a little thicker.  An incredible beer though.
This beer is amazing! Totally with the $25 price tag for such a small serving. I would really like to try the 07 as the 09 knocked my socks off!

I decided to open one of these to celebrate my engagement yesterday. 2009 vintage. Its also fitting that this is my 500th bottle review.

It pours a nice mahogany in color, between light and medium in body, with a slight beige lacing around the glass. The aromas are of candied sugar, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, bourbon, and oak. If you let it decant and swirl it about a bit you get some really elegant brandy notes, even some apple brandy. It smells great. It tastes of vanilla, cream, brown sugar, oak, cherries, port, brandy, bourbon, and has a superb smooth creamy finish. It is as if all of my tastebuds stood up to applaud. It instantly makes your mouth salivate. It drinks so smoothly and definitely makes you pay attention. This is a superb old ale, and a phenomenal barrel aged beer, period. I knew this one would be pretty stellar but it still surprised me. What a phenomenal beer, phenomenal.

Bottle. Poured into a tulip glass a darker caramel red color with a light coastered tan head that collars around the glass. Rich, bourbon, complex aroma that really is pleasing. Some booze in the nose. Nice sweet start with lots of caramel, oaky, and some booze. Alcohol adds an extra burn at the end. Medium mouthfeel. The booze warms the the throat. Quite the sipper for sure.

Had a bottle of this after my awesome pizza @ Waldos in KC .. . Pours a deep tan .. . this was so good! .. rich, full, bourbon, sweet molasses, fun, expensive .. . Youll have to speak up, Im wearing a towel.

2009 vintage, poured a nice maple syrup looking color, a nice amber with orange highlights.  Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, and toffee.  Flavors match the aroma and blended very well, also some sweet maple comes through towards the end.  As the beer warmed, more of the bourbon came through.

(500ml bottle thanks to BMan1113VR) rich, clear deep cognac color with soapy abundant tan bubbles. Nose of vanilla, bourbon, graham cracker, maple, honey, extremely complex nose. Big beer! Taste of vanilla, bourbon, maple, butter, waffles, big and delicious. Extremely decadent. One of the best beers of the day for sure.

A deep mahogany/toffee pour. What started out as an impressive head quickly sunk down into nothing. No lacing left behind in the rapture. Big bourbon aroma. Almost like I poured a huge glass of it. There is a raisin aroma buried in there as well. Not much else getting past the bourbon. Big sweet bourbony presence in the mouth. Big alcohol warmth. A slight maltiness, but the bourbon is winning out again. Sweet bourbon aftertaste. Nice bourbon. One I can actually drink.

Sampled at the High Rollers Tasting 2011.  2009 vintage.  Clear dark amber pour with ring of tan head.  Sweet bourbon/whisky nose. but mellow and vanilla and sweet falvor.  very tasty.  Syrupy thin body.  Good stuff, but not worth the price.

She is a beauty. pours dark like maple syrup with a light head that recedes leaving nothing to show. Aromas of french toast, peach cobbler, and graham crackers. Full nectar and unctuous with good carbonation. This lays heavily on the tongue but the bubbles push through effortlessly. This brew is a sipper, like fine Cognac you just want to savor every sip. Flavors similar to aroma with the addition of a pronounced Bourbon essence. Throw in some butterscotch, plum nectar and ginger. Above and beyond, this brew pushes the envelope. High density sweetness balanced by a bit of bittering and alcohol. The finish goes on and on.

2009 bottle thanks to a trade partner I believe, please excuse my forgetfulness! Pours a deep amber brown with a yellowish brown head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma is full of caramel, sweet bourbon and sweet grains and is not too boozy by any means. Flavor starts with sweet grains and bread and develops a nice bourbon note with a bit of a cookie sweetness. A bit sweet but nice.
09-on tap-pours a thin tan head and mahogany color.  Aroma is medium/dark malt-caramel, dark fruit, wood/bourbon.  Taste follows.

2009 bottle consumed 1/19/11.

sort of a orange auburn brown color with a small yellowy head.

it smells like figgy pound cake... covered in bourbon, vanilla and toffee.

the flavor shows some wood, umami and brown sugar on top of the notes from the aroma. the bourbon is soft and very well integrated.

it has a surprisingly thin body... which is great. i can keep drinking it! abv is very noted and really helps it from being sticky. 8/4/8.5/4/18

2009 purchased in June 2011 at Hop City Craft Beer in Atlanta, opened in July 2011. Pours a dark brown with a reddish tint. Carbonation bubbles quickly settle to no head, no lacing. Bourbon is very noticeable, but contrasts well with vanilla, raisin, figs. Medium mouthfeel. Fairly high carbonation for such a strong old ale, is messes with the flavors a bit. I really enjoy this beer. Id be curious to taste this one with a few more years on it.

500mL 2009 ed from Ricks in Alexandria, VA. The pour is a clear burnt umber with a fizzy, short lived yellow head. No retention or lace. The aroma is quite nice: very inviting rich buttery bourbon with bananas foster, rum cake, sherry, toffee. Taste is a little sweet cherry soda with cherry bourbon and no warming alcohol. Full richness of flavor with a clean, rather medium to light body. Very easy to drink with no warming alcohol. Could use more body and better appearance. I think this was actually forced carbonated because it had no head retention, fizzed wildly, and had no yeast sediment in the bottom of the bottle. Strange...maybe North Coast was tired of hearing about Lost Abbeys carbonation issues and just said "Fuck it."

Bottle. Pour is a bright copper with a nice yellow head and good retention. Aroma is big on oak, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, biscuit. Flavor is very similar to a bourbon coke - cherry, vanilla, cola, with toffee. Palate is quite hot, Id say if youre still holding on to a bottle give it another year.

2009 bottle purchased at Whole Foods, Scottsdale, AZ.  Pours a rich reddish/brown when held to a strong light.  Head is smallish tan color which quickly diminishes to a ring.  Little carbonation.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits and oak.  Taste is sweet (brown sugar), vanilla, dark fruit and smooth rich bourbon. Finish is warming bourbon, creamy and smooth.  This is one hell of a good ale.  Well done.

50cl bottle 2009 vintage.  Brown pour.  Nose of bourbon, toffee, and caramel.  Taste had those three plus some nice toasted sweet malt.  Unfortunetly not enough sweetness however.  Alcohol not well hidden.  Fairly thin mouth feel for a BA BW.

Pours hazy brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of oak, bourbon, vanilla, toffee,  and caramel.  Great nose.  Taste has tons of bourbon and creamy toffee.  Great sipping beer. Has nice alcohol burn in the finish.  Medium mouthfeel.  Tons of booze.  Awesome beer.

Poured from 50CL bottle.  Pours brown with TONS of carbonation.   The cork flew across the room.  Aroma was loads of bourbon.  Taste is really hot...some caramel.  I was disappointed in how thin this beer was.  I expected a bit more thickness, maybe some more sweetness.

2009 bottle from City Beer SF. Murky dark sultana, no head. Plum, raisin, vanilla, wood, caramel, bourbon, well balanced. Nice sweetness, well carbonated, finish is a little hot with bourbon and port notes, but still excellent. Could do with some more age but still great.
09 bottle shared by Seth.  Clear amber pour with a faint white head.  Big bourbon nose.  Booze, caramel malt, and dark fruit flavors.

2009 bottle. Pours deep mahogany with virtually no head and boozy legs. Aroma of bourbon, toffee, lots of dark fruit, oak and  vanilla. Flavor is lots of sweet sugar and caramel malt with a big bourbon warming. Medium to full body with prickly carbonation and a slick, almost oily mouth feel. This is a great boozy, barley wine but the $25 price tag is a bit steep.

09 bottle.  Strong bourbon nose with raisins, plums, tobacco, and caramel.  Nice.  The pour is a dark reddish-brown color with a good off-white head that quickly settles as a  light ring around the glass.  This is very soothing going down with some gentle alcohol warmth.  Plenty of bourbon flavor but it doesnt become too one dimensional.  Raisins, dates, caramel, barrel notes, vanilla, and even a dash of chocolate join in.  Good carbonation.  This is expensive stuff but its a tasty treat for sure.

6/10/11. 500mL bottle thanks to Byron at LL/Proof! Clear dark red pour with a small tan head that fades to a ring fast. Awesome BA aroma with coconut, vanilla, butter, oak, and more - all on top of a nice, sweet, fruity base. Awesome. Sweet brown sugar on the front of the flavor with lingering BA characteristics including coconut and big sweet vanilla. Damn this is good!

UPDATED: APR 19, 2015 2009;  Well balanced burbon and malt nose.  I get that caramel vanilla burbon flavors, some dark fruits are present.  Very smooth.  Finish is very clean.  The alcohol is well hidden.  Fantastic beer, its sooo expensive.July 2011.  addition 2013 bottle rerated 2015.  Again very smooth, Burns into the finish. Great but still expensive.

Neat faux ceramic painted bottle, corked and caged, 2009 vintage: Abundant hot bourbon aroma, but good quality bourbon I must add. Walnuts, shorttbread, pecans, and maple syrup are also very prominent on the nose. Crystal clear garnet brown, thick yellow head. Dates and figs initially. with a surge of smooth bourbon at midpalate. Finishes with oak, cherries, and cream. Body is a tad too thin for the style and I tend to like thinner barleywines. My son and I both spontaneously picked up on a mild anesthetic effect in the back of our throats after drinking it. He asked me to add that.  Exquisite. North Coast obviously went to great lengths to craft and brew this beer and it came out wonderful. Move over Old Rasputin, this may be North Coasts best creation.

2009 vintage. Pours. Pours hazy reddish brown color with almost no head. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla and oak. Sweet caramel flavor with loads of bourbon. A little vanilla and a hint of oak. Medium to full body with almost no carbonation. A little better than the original but much more expensive.

Pours a rich mahogany with very little head. Smell is deep caramel, malts, bourbon, and loads of oak. The flavor is much the same. Good brew, little thin and at times a little one-dimensional. On the sweet side.

Thanks to beerchugger for sharing this big brew! Pours ruby in color with just a touch of white head. Smells of vanilla, toffee, chocolate, bourbon and licorice. Toffee, chocolate, raisins, bourbon and molasses. Mouthfeel is thick and the finish is sweet that is medium in length.

Tallahassee, Fl - Proof Friday night tasting - many thanks to Byron for giving this to drowland! Dark copper pour, light white head. Aroma of coconut and vanilla. Flavor is luxuriously silky and smooth. Pick up subtle bourbon accents - but it stays nice and quiet in the corner. Some kids cereal sweetness, a hint of chocolate, coconut and vanilla. Mouthfeel is thick and rich. Excellent - glad I finally got to try this.

Bottle from 2009.  Aroma has notes of bourbon whiskey, sweet caramel malts, oak, booze and toffee.  Deep burgundy brown hue with a small light tan head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and boozy.  Palate is very full bodied and oily average with a long finish.  Overall a nice bourbon barely wine thats pleasant.  The bourbon is a bit overpowering on everything else.  Decent.

500 ml brown painted bottle at a ridiculous $22.99. The bottle looks like it came from the 1800s or something. Poured a somewhat murky dark reddish brown in a tulip with a small fast fading head. The aroma has a nice medium to strong bourbon barrel character. Just from the aroma alone the base beer(Old Stock) really picked up the barrel character quite well. Lots of vanilla, wood and caramel. The taste is very easy and smooth for the ABV and the fact that its a bourbon barrel barleywine. lots of caramel without being overly sweet, vanilla, wood. Now the middle of the taste seems to fall flat and kind of drifts but no complaints. The palate is very soft and somewhat sticky. My overall score would  be a little higher had the price not been so absurd. Lets see $12-$14 for 48 oz. of the standard Old Stock. While this is $23.00 for almost 17 oz. I do not know if other breweries barrel aged beers have that high of a markup but I guess people buy it.

Pours dark murky brownish with pretty much no head, aroma has notes of vanilla, bourbon, caramel, deep toffee and rich chocolate and molasses notes.  Decadent.  Taste is sweet bourbon and vanilla, with caramel and thick toffee, some honey, molasses, chocolate, and some really nice sweet vanilla on the back.  Delicious, creamy, thick and just enough carb to pull it through the palate.

Pours ruby-tinged mahogany into a snifter. Off-white head crackles and recedes to nothing. Bourbon, vanilla and marinade aromas. Sweet vanilla, licorice, soy and spices upfront turning to a lasting maple and oak finish.

Appearance: deep mahoganies, lightly worn with age and time. No real head, just a few bubbly wisps which disappear as fast as they appear.
